501.04
 
 
101.01  DESIGNATION;  CITATION;  HEADINGS.
   (a)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Lexington, Ohio 1998,  for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted.  Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)   All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified.  Any
component code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic
Code".  Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section"
followed by the number, such as "Section 101.01".
101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)   "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it.
      (ORC 1.02(F))
   (b)   "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
      (ORC 1.02(B))
   (c)   "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
      (ORC 1.02(D), (E))
   (d)   "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (e)   "County" means Richland County, Ohio.
   (f)   "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
   (g)   "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature.
      (ORC 701.01(F))
   (h)   "Municipality" or "Village " means the Municipality of Lexington,
Ohio.
   (i)   "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm. 
      (ORC 1.59(B))
   (j)   "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (k)   "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
      (ORC 1.59(C))
   (l)   "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (m)   "Property" means real and personal property.
      (ORC 1.59(E))
      "Personal property" includes all property except real.
      "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)   "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any
duly authorized public official.
   (o)   "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (p)   "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail"
includes registered mail.
      (ORC 1.02(G))
   (q)   "Rule" includes regulation.  (ORC 1.59(F))
   (r)   "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (s)   "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio.
      (ORC 1.59(G))
   (t)   "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (u)   "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (v)   "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners; 
principals, agents and employees;  and all officials, public or private.
      (ORC 1.02(A))
   (w)   "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols or figures.  This provision does not affect any law relating
to signatures.
      (ORC 1.59(J))
101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Usage.  Words and phrases shall be read in
context and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. 
Words and phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether
by legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense.  As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future.
         (ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Calendar; Computation of Time.
      (1)   Definitions.
         A.   "Week" means seven consecutive days.
         B.   "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
            (ORC 1.44)
      (2)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
         (ORC 1.45)
      (3)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
   When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be performed, is
closed to the public for the entire day which constitutes the last day for
doing such act or before its usual closing time on such day, then such act may
be performed on the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal
holiday.  If any legal holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is a
legal holiday.
         (ORC 1.14)
      (4)   When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and
after a day named, no part of that day shall be included.
         (ORC 1.15)
      (5)   In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice.
   (d)   Authority.  When the law requires an act to be done which may by law
as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)   Joint Authority.  All words purporting to give joint authority to
three or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving
such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall
be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)   Exceptions.  The rules of construction shall not apply to any law
which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when
the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
101.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(ORC 1.54)
   (c)   The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not, except
as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the
ordinance had not been repealed or amended.
   (d)   If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced by
a re-enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture, or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re-enactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (c)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
101.06  CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)   If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(ORC 1.46)
   (b)   If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both.  If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(ORC 1.51)
   (c)   (1)   If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
      (2)   If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different
meetings of Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments
are to be harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each.  If the
amendments are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment
prevails.  The fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an
earlier amendment, or fails to include language inserted by an earlier
amendment, does not of itself make the amendments irreconcilable.  Amendments
are irreconcilable only when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into
simultaneous operation.
         (ORC 1.52)
101.07  DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)   In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
      (1)   Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United
States is intended;
      (2)   The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
      (3)   A just and reasonable result is intended;
      (4)   A result feasible of execution is intended.
         (ORC 1.47)
   (b)   An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(ORC 1.48)
   (c)   If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
      (1)   The object sought to be attained;
      (2)   The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
      (3)   The legislative history;
      (4)   The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws
upon the same or similar subjects;
      (5)   The consequences of a particular construction;
      (6)   The administrative construction of the ordinance.
         (ORC 1.49)
101.08  SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00).  A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.
                                                                               
                                         
CHAPTER 103
Official Standards
103.01 Use of Municipal seal.

1.01
 
 
 
103.01  USE OF MUNICIPAL SEAL.
   (a)   The following terms and conditions hereby apply to the use of the
municipal seal:
(1)   Use of the official seal of the Municipality is protected by copyright
and any unauthorized use is strictly prohibited.  The municipal seal shall not
be used in a degrading or demeaning manner and the Municipality reserves the
right to void this permit if in its sole opinion, the use of its official seal
is improper or violates the terms of this application in any way.
(2)   The Municipality also prohibits the assignment of rights to the use of
this seal to any individual or organization other than the original applicant
or for other than the specific purposes stated in this application.
(3)   Applicants shall use the municipal seal in its exact form and any
modifications, alterations or changes, except for size, violate the conditions
of this agreement and the user of such altered seal may be guilty of copyright
infringement.
   (b)   The Administrative Director is hereby directed to accept applications
for the use of the municipal seal and to collect from each a license fee of ten
dollars ($10.00).
   (c)   Any use of this seal in violation of the provisions of this section
shall constitute a minor misdemeanor.
(1980 Code 10.16)
                                                                               
                                         
CHAPTER 105
Municipal Property
105.01   Smoking prohibited in Municipal Building.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appropriation of property - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 719
Sale or lease of property - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 721
 
 
 
105.01  SMOKING PROHIBITED IN MUNICIPAL BUILDING.
   (a)   No person shall consume tobacco in any form such as by placing in the
mouth or nose, nor smoke or have in their possession lighted tobacco in any
form within the Lexington Municipal Building.
   (b)   Whoever shall violate the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, shall
be guilty of a minor misdemeanor upon the first offense and upon a second or
subsequent offense within one year of the first, a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.  In addition, any employee of the Village who shall violate subsection
(a) hereof shall be subject to discipline for insubordination in accordance
with the procedure set forth in the Village Personnel Handbook.
   (c)   The Village Administrator shall post signs at such locations as he
shall deem appropriate stating the prohibition in this section.
(Ord. 01-52.  Passed 12-17-01.)
                                                                               
                                             
CHAPTER 107

107.05   Approval of Mayor and Council's travel expenses.

CROSS REFERENCES
State law applicable - see CHTR.

131.01
 
 
 
107.01  MEALS AND REFRESHMENT EXPENDITURES.
   (a)   The Municipal Administrative Director is hereby authorized to expend
from the Boards and Commissions Account in the Municipal General Fund
Administrative Accounts money to pay for meals and nonalcoholic refreshments
for officials and employees of this Municipality and other persons having
business with this Municipality, which expenditures tend to serve and assist in
the performance of the governmental functions of the Municipality.
   (b)   All such expenditures shall be documented in a matter satisfactory
with the Municipal Finance Director and shall never exceed the amount 
appropriated for this purpose by Council.
   (c)   All expenditures made pursuant to the authority of this section shall
be only in accordance with guidelines hereafter to be established by this
Council.
(1980 Code 30.07)
107.02  INDEPENDENT AUDIT WHEN NEW OFFICER ASSUMES DUTIES.
   (a)   Whenever a new person assumes the duties of Mayor, Income Tax Clerk,
Water and Sewer Clerk, Clerk of Mayor's Court, or Finance Director, an
independent audit of the accounts, records, and funds under the control of that
official shall be ordered by Council.
   (b)   The audit shall be conducted by an independent public accountant
selected by Council, shall cover the term of the predecessor in office of the
new official, and shall be of such scope and nature as Council shall direct.
   (c)   Whenever a new person assumes any other position with the Municipality
except those specified in subsection (a) hereof, which involves the handling of
or access to public funds, the Finance Director shall conduct an immediate
audit of the accounts, records, and funds of the position and make a full
report to Council.
(1980 Code 35.01)
107.03  DISHONORED CHECK SERVICE CHARGE.
   (a)   There is hereby established a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for
each check payable to the Municipality which is dishonored and returned by the
drawee bank for any reason.  Each Municipal employee responsible for the
collection of the original payment shall assess the twenty-five dollar ($25.00)
fee established by this section and collect the same from the person who owes
the principal obligation in addition to that underlying amount.
   (b)   No payment for which a service charge has been assessed shall be
accepted unless accompanied by the service charge created by this section. 
(1980 Code 35.06)
107.04  SERVICE CHARGE ON OVERDUE PAYMENTS.
   (a)   Except in those cases in which a service or other charge for delayed
payment is otherwise specifically provided, there is hereby levied upon all
sums due to this Municipality a service charge in the sum of one and one-half
percent (1-1/2%) per month or ten dollars ($10.00) per month whichever is the
larger upon all debts owed to this Municipality which are not paid within
thirty days of the date of invoice.
   (b)   The Finance Director is hereby directed to assess and collect the
service charge provided in subsection (a) hereof upon all moneys not paid
within thirty days.
(1980 Code 35.07)
107.05  APPROVAL OF MAYOR AND COUNCIL'S TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   (a)   No member of Council nor the Mayor shall be reimbursed for travel
expenses incurred on behalf of this Municipality unless a request on a form
provided is submitted to the Finance Director and approved by a motion adopted
by a majority vote of Council prior to the proposed travel.
   (b)   The application shall contain the following information:
      (1)   Purpose of travel.
      (2)   Dates of travel.
      (3)   Estimated expenses for:
         A.   Transportation;
         B.   Meals;
         C.   Lodging;
         D.   Registration;
         E.   Miscellaneous expense, such as parking or tolls.
   (c)   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to eliminate the
requirement that actual receipts be provided to the Finance Director as
required by law after the travel is completed to justify reimbursement.
   (d)   The Finance Director is authorized to pay from funds appropriated for
this purpose the actual expenses incurred provided prior approval was obtained
as provided in this section and the actual expenses do not exceed the estimated
expenses in a significant amount.
(1980 Code 35.08)
107.06  PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT IN AREAS TO BE ANNEXED.
   It is hereby declared to be the policy of this Municipality that the
construction of public improvements in areas to be hereinafter annexed to this
Municipality shall be paid for by special assessments upon the lots and lands
specifically benefitted to the maximum extent permitted by law.
   This policy shall apply to the construction or reconstruction of streets,
storm sewers, sanitary sewers, water lines and related appurtenances unless it
shall be specifically modified by Council with respect to a specific project.
(1980 Code 35.09)
107.07  DEPOSIT AND INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   (a)   The deposit and investment of Municipal funds shall be conducted in
such a manner as to guarantee the total safety of Municipal money, meet the
cash flow requirements of Municipal operations and provide a maximum return on
deposits and investments consistent with the other provisions of this section.
   (b)   The Finance Director shall, with the consultation of the Mayor and Law
Director, determine the amount, type and length of time of all deposits and
investments of Village money within the perimeters of this section.
   (c)   All Village money shall be deposited at eligible depositories having
offices within this Village and in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C.
Chapter 135 known as the Uniform Depository Act.  In the alternative, Village
money may be deposited in the State Treasurer’s Investment Pool (Star Ohio) in
accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 135.45- 135.46 or in any other
program where the deposit or investment is fully guaranteed as to principal and
interest by the State of Ohio or the United States. (Ord. 03-18.  Passed 5-5-
03.)
   (d)   No deposit or investment shall have a maturity date of more than five
years from the date of deposit or investment without the approval of the
Deposit and Investment Board.
   (e)   The Finance Director shall diversify all deposits and investments to
the extent permitted by law in order to meet the cash flow requirements of the
Municipality and minimize the risk of loss from default by any depository
institution.
   (f)   The Finance Director shall report at least quarterly to the Deposit
and Investment Board and to the Finance Committee of Council on the status and
results of all deposits and investments.
(1980 Code 35.10)
107.08  LINE ITEM ADJUSTMENTS IN APPROPRIATIONS.
   The Administrative Director is hereby granted authority to adjust up to a
maximum of ten percent (10%) in an appropriated line item in the temporary or
permanent appropriation ordinance.  This authority shall be subject to the
following limitation:
   (a)   No change in the total fund appropriation may be made.
   (b)   No adjustment shall exceed the increase or decrease of any line item
by more than one thousand dollars ($1,000).
   (c)   All adjustments shall have the prior approval of the Mayor.
   (d)   The Finance Director and the chairman of the Finance Committee of
Council shall be promptly notified of all actions by the Administrative
Director pursuant to this section and the reasons therefor.
   (e)   All changes shall include corresponding adjustments so that total fund
appropriation shall remain unchanged.
      (1980 Code 35.11)
                                                                               
                                         
CHAPTER 109
Public Records
109.01   Introduction.
109.02   Requests in person.
109.03   Requests by telephone.
109.04   Requests by mail, e-mail or in person.
109.05   Costs of copies.
109.06   Redaction.
109.07   Records not information.
109.08   Goal of policy.
109.09   Reasonable time.
109.10   Conclusion.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Access to public records - see Oho R.C. 149.43
 
 
109.01  INTRODUCTION.
   The Village recognizes the right of the public to access during regular
business hours to all public records of this Village.  The purpose of this
policy is to facilitate the access to those records to avoid the cost to the
taxpayers of duplication of records that are not requested and to allow
requests to be met in a timely and efficient manner.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.02  REQUESTS IN PERSON.
   Any person may request to inspect and obtain copies at cost of any public
records by visiting the Village Hall, 44 West Main Street, during regular
business hours.  In order to avoid errors, requests for copies shall be in
writing.  A Village employee shall be present during record inspection.  (Ord.
05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.03  REQUESTS BY TELEPHONE.
   In order to avoid the errors in producing copies of records other than those
requested, requests for copies of records made over the telephone will not be
honored unless followed by a written or e-mail request so that the exact
records requested can be provided.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.04  REQUESTS BY MAIL, E-MAIL OR IN PERSON.
   Upon receipt of a request for copies of records, the Village shall advise
the applicant of the cost of the copies as well as the cost of postage and
mailing supplies if the applicant chooses to receive the records by mail.  Upon
receipt of the amount requested, the Village shall promptly provide the
requested copies.  Since not all records are kept in electronic format as an
integral part of the normal operations of the Village, the copies will be
provided on paper unless it can be supplied on the medium in which it is kept
and the applicant requests the record in that medium.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.05  COST OF COPIES.
   The cost of each copy shall be ten cents (10¢) per page.  No Village
employee is authorized to waive this charge for any applicant.  The cost of
postage and mailing materials shall be the actual cost incurred by the
Village.  There shall be no cost charged for viewing public records, only for
copies. 
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.06  REDACTION.
   In addition to its legal obligation to make public records available upon
request, the Village has a comparable obligation not to release documents
containing information which is confidential or protected by the right of
privacy as defined by the Ohio Supreme Court.  Information that is confidential
or private will be redacted from all records before release.  In the case of
doubt as to whether a document should be released at all or with some
information redacted, the Law Director shall be consulted.  (Ord. 05-16. 
Passed 3-21-05.)
109.07  RECORDS NOT INFORMATION.
   The law of Ohio requires public records, not public information to be
released.  It does not require the creation of records that do not exist nor
the interpretation of information in public records.  Village employees are
directed to refrain from these activities and direct the inquirers for
information rather than documents to appropriate official, e.g. Administrative
Director, Finance Director, Law Director, Police Chief or Mayor.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.08  GOAL OF POLICY.
   The Village recognizes that the records it possesses belong to the public,
not to Village officials.  However, Village officials have an obligation to
preserve these records in an orderly manner to avoid making copies of records
not requested, which is a waste of taxpayers’ money, and not to release any
record that is either not a public record or contains information which is not
public information unless that information has been redacted from the record.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.09  REASONABLE TIME.
   While the term “reasonable time” is not subject to precise definition in the
abstract, it is used in two senses in the law.  Records must be made available
for inspection at all reasonable times during regular business hours.  A
request to inspect records just before the end of regular business hours need
not be honored if it would require the employee to work overtime.  The
applicant should be directed to return during business hours.  Copies are also
to be provided within a reasonable time.  While an exact time limit cannot be
set, the volume of the request as well as other duties of the employee are
factors to be considered.  Generally, requests should be processed within three
workdays, but voluminous record requests may take longer.  Effort should be
made to fill requests as soon as possible particularly if the request is for
only a few pages, but reasonable time does not mean immediately.  Compliance
with records requests is not given by law priority over other duties of the
employee.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
109.10  CONCLUSION.
   The purpose of this policy is to allow the Village to fully comply with Ohio
R.C. 149.43 in a manner that will promote the availability of public records
and maintain the efficiency and economy of Village administrative operations.
(Ord. 05-16.  Passed 3-21-05.)
CHAPTER 111
Identity Theft Policy
111.01   Background
111.02   Purpose.
111.03   Scope.
111.04   Policy.
111.05   Additional identity theft prevention program.
111.06   Responding to red flags.
111.07   Periodic updates to plan.
111.08   Program administration.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Identity fraud - see Ohio R.C. 2913.49
         Forgery of identification cards - see GEN. OFF.
545.20
   111.01  BACKGROUND.
   The Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act of 2003, an amendment to the
Fair Credit Reporting Act, requires rules regarding identity theft protection
to be promulgated.
(Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.02  PURPOSE.
   (a)   The Village adopts this sensitive information policy to help protect
employees, customers, contractors and the Village from damages related to the
loss or misuse of sensitive information.  This policy will:
      (1)   Define sensitive information;
      (2)   Describe the physical security of data when it is printed on paper;
      (3)   Describe the electronic security of data when stored and
distributed; and
      (4)   Place the Village in compliance with state and federal law
regarding identity theft protection.
   (b)   This policy enables the Village to protect existing customers,
reducing risk from identity fraud, and minimize potential damage to the Village
from fraudulent new accounts. The program will help the Village:
      (1)   Identify risks that signify potentially fraudulent activity within
new or existing covered accounts;
      (2)   Detect risks when they occur in covered accounts;
      (3)   Respond to risks to determine if fraudulent activity has occurred
and act if fraud has been attempted or committed; and
      (4)   Update the program periodically, including reviewing the accounts
that are covered and the identified risks that are part of the program.
         (Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.03  SCOPE.
   This policy and protection program applies to employees, contractors,
consultants, temporary workers, and other workers at the Village, including all
personnel affiliated with third parties. 
(Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.04  POLICY.
   (a)   Sensitive Information Policy.
      (1)   Definition of sensitive information.
         A.   Sensitive information includes the following items whether stored
in electronic or printed format:
            1.    Name, social security number, date of birth, official State
or government issued drivers license or identification number, alien
registration number, government passport number, employer or taxpayer
identification number;
            2.   Unique biometric data, such as fingerprint, voice print,
retina or iris image, or other unique physical representation;
            3.   Unique electronic identification number, address, or routing
code; or
            4.    Telecommunication identifying information or access devise
(as defined in 18 U.S.C.,1029(e)).
         B.   Village personnel are encouraged to use common sense judgment in
securing confidential information to the proper extent. Furthermore, this
section should be read in conjunction with the Ohio Public Records Law and the
Village's  open records policy. If an employee is uncertain of the sensitivity
of a particular piece of information, he/she should contact their supervisor.
In the  event that the Village cannot resolve a conflict between this policy
and the Ohio Public Records Law, the Village will contact the Village's legal
counsel.
      (2)   Hard copy distribution.  Each employee and contractor performing
work for the Village will comply with the following policies:
         A.   File cabinets, desk drawers, overhead cabinets, and any other
storage space containing documents with sensitive information will be locked
when not in use.
         B.   Storage rooms containing documents with sensitive information and
record retention areas will be locked at the end of each workday or when
unsupervised.
         C.   Desks, workstations, work areas, printers and fax machines, and
common shared work areas will be cleared of all documents containing sensitive
information when not in use.
         D.   Whiteboards, dry-erase boards, writing tablets, etc. in common
shared work areas will be erased, removed, or shredded when not in use.
         E.   Municipal records, however, may only be destroyed in accordance
with the Village's records retention policy.
      (3)   Electronic distribution.
         A.   Each employee and contractor performing work for the Village will
comply with the following policies:
            1.   Internally, sensitive information may be transmitted using
approved municipal e- mail. All sensitive information must be encrypted when
stored in an electronic format.
            2.    Any sensitive information sent externally must be encrypted
and password protected and only to approved recipients. Additionally, a
statement such as this should be included in the email:
   "This message may contain confidential and/or proprietary information and is
intended for the person/entity to whom it was originally addressed.  Any use by
others is strictly prohibited".
         (Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.05  ADDITIONAL IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM.
   (a)   Covered Accounts.  A covered account includes any account that
involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions. Every new
and existing customer account that meets the following criteria is covered by
this program:
      (1)   Business, personal and household accounts for which there is a
reasonably foreseeable risk of identity theft; or
      (2)   Business, personal and household accounts for which there is a
reasonably foreseeable risk to the safety or soundness of the Village from
identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or
litigation risks.
   (b)   Red Flags.
      (1)   The following red flags are potential indicators of fraud. Any time
a red flag, or a situation closely resembling a red flag, is apparent, it
should be investigated for verification.
         A.   Alerts, notifications or warnings from a consumer reporting
agency;
         B.   A fraud or active duty alert included with a consumer report;
         C.   A notice of credit freeze from a consumer reporting agency in
response to a request for a consumer report; or
         D.   A notice of address discrepancy from a consumer reporting agency
as defined in  §334.82(b) of the Fairness and Accuracy in Credit Transactions
Act.
      (2)   Red flags also include consumer reports that indicate a pattern of
activity inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an
applicant or customer, such as:
         A.   A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries; an
unusual number of recently established credit relationships;
         B.   A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect
to recently established credit relationships; or
         C.   An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of
account privileges by a financial institution or creditor.
   (c)   Suspicious Documents.
      (1)   Documents provided for identification that appear to have been
altered or forged.
      (2)   The photograph or physical description on the identification is not
consistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer presenting the
identification.
      (3)   Other information on the identification is not consistent with
information provided by the person opening a new covered account or customer
presenting the identification.
      (4)   Other information on the identification is not consistent with
readily accessible information that is on file with the Village, such as a
signature card or a recent check.
      (5)   An application appears to have been altered or forged, or gives the
appearance of having been destroyed and reassembled.
   (d)   Suspicious Personal Identifying Information.
      (1)   Personal identifying information provided is inconsistent when
compared against external information sources used by the Village. For example:
         A.   The address does not match any address in the consumer report;
         B.   The Social Security number (SSN) has not been issued or is listed
on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File; or
         C.   Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not
consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the
customer. For example, there is a lack of correlation between the SSN range and
date of birth.
      (2)   Personal identifying information provided is associated with known
fraudulent activity as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the
Village. For example, the address on an application is the same as the address
provided on a fraudulent application.
      (3)   Personal identifying information provided is of a type commonly
associated with fraudulent activity as indicated by internal or third-party
sources used by the Village. For example:
         A.   The address on an application is fictitious, a mail drop, or a
prison; or
         B.   The phone number is invalid or is associated with a pager or
answering service.
      (4)   The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other persons
opening an account or other customers.
      (5)   The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar
to the address or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of
other customers or other persons opening accounts.
      (6)   The customer or the person opening the covered account fails to
provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in
response to notification that the application is incomplete.
      (7)   Personal identifying information provided is not consistent with
personal identifying information that is on file with the Village.
      (8)   When using security questions (mother's maiden name, pet's name,
etc.), the person opening the covered account or the customer cannot provide
authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from
a wallet or consumer report.
   (e)   Unusual Use Of, or Suspicious Activity Related To, the Covered
Account.
      (1)   Shortly following the notice of a change of address for a covered
account, the Village receives a request for new, additional, or replacement
goods or services, or for the addition of authorized users on the account.
      (2)   A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly
associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example, the customer
fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent
payments.
      (3)   A covered account is used in a manner that is not consistent with
established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example:
         A.   Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments;
         B.   Severe swings in consumption. For example, 1,000 kwh to 3,000
kwh.
      (4)   A covered account that has been inactive for a reasonably lengthy
period of time is used (taking into consideration the type of account, the
expected pattern of usage and other relevant factors).
      (5)   Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable
although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the
customer's covered account.
      (6)   The Village is notified that the customer is not receiving paper
account statements.
      (7)   The Village is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in
connection with a customer's covered account.
      (8)   The Village receives notice from customers, victims of identity
theft, law enforcement authorities, or other persons regarding possible
identity theft in connection with covered accounts held by the Village.
      (9)   The Village is notified by a customer, a victim of identity theft,
a law enforcement authority, or any other person that it has opened a
fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft.
         (Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.06  RESPONDING TO RED FLAGS.
   (a)   Once potentially fraudulent activity is detected, an employee must act
quickly as a rapid appropriate response can protect customers and the Village
from damages and loss.
      (1)   Once potentially fraudulent activity is detected, gather all
related documentation and write a description of the situation. Present this
information to the designated authority for determination.
      (2)   The designated authority will complete additional authentication to
determine whether the attempted transaction was fraudulent or authentic.
   (b)   If a transaction is determined to be fraudulent, appropriate actions
must be taken immediately. Actions may include:
      (1)   Canceling the transaction;
      (2)   Notifying and cooperating with appropriate law enforcement;
      (3)   Determining the extent of liability of the Village; and
      (4)   Notifying the actual customer that fraud has been attempted.
         (Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.07  PERIODIC UPDATES TO PLAN.
   (a)   At periodic intervals established in the program, or as required, the
program will be re-evaluated to determine whether all aspects of the program
are up to date and applicable in the current business environment. The
Village's Records Commission shall regularly assess the actual operation of the
Village's Identity Theft Policy and recommend amendments to Council as needed.
   (b)   Periodic reviews will include an assessment of which accounts are
covered by the program.
   (c)   As part of the review, red flags may be revised, replaced or
eliminated.  Defining new red flags may also be appropriate.
   (d)   Actions to take in the event that fraudulent activity is discovered
may also require revision to reduce damage to the Village and its customers.
(Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)
   111.08  PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION.
   (a)   Involvement of Management.
      (1)   The Identity Theft Prevention Program shall not be operated as an
extension to existing fraud prevention programs, and its importance warrants
the highest level of attention.
      (2)   The Identity Theft Prevention Program is the responsibility of the
Village Administrator. Approval of the initial plan must be appropriately
documented and maintained.
      (3)   Operational responsibility of the program is delegated to the
Village Administrator.
      (4)   The Administrative Director shall have the authority to delegate to
and appoint Village employees to administer the Identity Theft Policy.
      (5)   The Administrative Director shall provide regular reports to the
Village's Records Commission regarding the administration and enforcement of
the Identity Theft Policy.
   (b)   Staff Training.
      (1)   Staff training shall be conducted for all employees, officials and
contractors for whom it is reasonably foreseeable that they may come into
contact with accounts or personally identifiable information that may
constitute a risk to the Village or its customers.
      (2)   The Administrative Director is responsible for ensuring identity
theft training for all requisite employees and contractors.
      (3)   Employees must receive regular training in all elements of this
policy.
      (4)   To ensure maximum effectiveness, employees may continue to receive
additional training as changes to the program are made.
   (c)   Oversight of Service Provider Arrangements.
      (1)   It is the responsibility of the Village to ensure that the
activities of all service providers are conducted in accordance with reasonable
policies and procedures designed to detect, prevent, and mitigate the risk of
identity theft.
      (2)   A service provider that maintains its own identity theft prevention
program, consistent with the guidance of the red flag rules and validated by
appropriate due diligence, may be considered to be meeting these requirements.
      (3)   Any specific requirements should be specifically addressed in the
appropriate contract arrangements.
         (Ord. 08-36.  Passed 11-3-08.)

121.01  REGULAR MEETINGS.
   Regular meetings of Council shall be held in the Council Chambers at 7:30
p.m. on the first and third Mondays respectively of each month except that
during the months of June, July, and August, regular Council meetings shall be
held only on the first Monday of these months.  Council may, by majority vote,
change the day and hour of holding any regular meeting, or adjourn the same to
a day and hour determined by a like vote of the members present if constituting
a quorum.
   Council shall meet in caucus fifteen minutes prior to each regular Council
meeting for the purpose of reviewing the agenda for the upcoming meeting.
(Ord. 02-23.  Passed 6-17-02; Ord. 03-15.  Passed 4-7-03.)
121.02  SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Council shall hold such special meetings as may be found necessary, which
may  be called by the Mayor or on request of three members of Council. Such
vote or request for the calling of a special meeting shall state the subject to
be considered thereat, and no other subject shall be considered except on the
approval of two-thirds of the members of Council in attendance at such special
meeting. Twenty-four hours' notice in writing of such special meeting, if
called by the Mayor or by three members of Council, shall be given to each
member of Council and to the Mayor by personal service or by delivery thereof
at their usual places of residence. Members of Council may waive such notice by
their attendance at such special meeting. The Mayor or any member of Council
who is present at any meeting at which a special meeting is announced need not
receive notice of the special meeting.
(1980 Code 30.11)
121.03  ROLL CALL.
   The Mayor, or in his absence the President Pro Tempore of Council, shall
take the chair at the hour appointed for Council to meet and immediately shall
call the Council to order. The roll shall then be called by the Clerk, who
shall enter in the journal of each meeting the names of members present. In the
absence of a quorum at the time appointed for a meeting, the members present
may by a majority vote take a recess or recesses and cause the Clerk to contact
absent members.
(1980 Code 30.12)
121.04  TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.
   In case of the absence of the Mayor and the President Pro Tempore, the Clerk
shall call the Council to order. The Clerk shall call the roll and if a quorum
is found to be present, the Council shall proceed to elect by a majority vote a
Temporary Chairman of the meeting until the appearance of the Mayor or
President Pro Tempore.
(1980 Code 30.13)
121.05  SUBSTITUTE CHAIRMAN.
   The Chair, that is the Mayor, President Pro Tempore, or Temporary Chairman,
may call any other member to take his place in the Chair, such substitution not
to continue beyond adjournment.
(1980 Code 30.14)
121.06  APPEALS FROM DECISIONS OF THE CHAIR.
   The Chair shall preserve decorum and refer all questions of order to the
Parliamentarian, subject to appeal to Council. If any member transgresses the
rules of Council, the Chair shall, or any member may, call him to order and in
the latter instance the Parliamentarian shall render a decision as to the point
of order. In case of an appeal from a ruling of the Chair, the question shall
be, "Shall the decision of the Chair stand as the decision of Council?"
   The Chair shall be sustained unless overruled by a majority vote of the
members of Council present.
(1980 Code 30.15)
121.07  VOTES.
   All questions shall be stated and put by the Chair by roll call votes. The
Chair shall declare the vote after the Clerk has announced the number of votes
on each side.
(1980 Code 30.16)
121.08  CHAIR'S POWER TO VOTE.
   The Mayor shall have no veto power, and shall have no vote except in the
event of a tie vote of members of Council present, in which case the Mayor
shall have the power to vote and his vote shall have the same legal effect as a
vote of a member of Council. Any member of Council who is serving as Chairman
shall have the same power to vote as other members, except the Mayor shall have
no vote on any matter in which the Charter requires the Council to approve or
concur in an action of the Mayor.
(1980 Code 30.17)
121.09  MEMBERS' DUTIES AND PRIVILEGES.
   For all purposes, except seconding motions, no member shall be entitled to
any of the floor privileges until he addresses the Chair as "Mr. Mayor," Mr.
President," or "Mr. Chairman," who shall pronounce the name of the member
entitled to the floor. Members addressing Council shall confine themselves to
the question under debate and avoid personalities. No member shall be
privileged to disturb or interrupt another member having the floor, except by a
call to order.
(1980 Code 30.18)
121.10  LIMITATION OF DEBATE.
   No member shall be allowed to speak more than once on any one subject until
every member choosing to speak shall have spoken, nor for a time longer than
five minutes, without leave of Council as expressed by a majority vote of the
members present.
(1980 Code 30.19)
121.11  VOTING.
   Every member present when a question is put shall vote on the question
unless Council shall for special reason excuse him from voting. The excuse
shall be granted only if the member states reasons for the request before
voting begins and the Council by majority vote of the members present accepts
them.
(1980 Code 30.20)
121.12  CONSIDERING ORDINANCES.
   (a)    Any member of Council has the privilege to bring legislation before a
regular session of Council.
   (b)    Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, Council
shall not be required to consider any legislation unless the following
conditions exist.
      (1)    The subject matter contained in the legislation has been reviewed
and considered by a standing committee of Council.
      (2)    If the legislation requires new funding not provided in the
current appropriation ordinance whether expressly or by transfer from an
existing line item, the legislation shall also have been reviewed by the
Council Finance Committee.
   (c)    Council may by a two-thirds vote of Council members present at a
regular meeting dispense with either or both of the requirements contained in
subsection (b) hereof.
(1980 Code 30.21)
121.13  ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The business of Council shall be conducted in the following order.
   (a)    Roll call.
   (b)   Pledge of Allegiance.
   (c)    Approval of minutes.
   (d)    Fixing the time for adjournment.
   (e)    Communications from citizens.
   (f)    Committee reports.
   (g)    Administrative Director's report.
   (h)    Engineer's report.
   (i)    Mayor's report.
   (j)    Police Chief's report.
   (k)    Parliamentarian's report.
   (l)   Ordinances and resolutions.
   (m)    New business.
   (n)    Old business.
   (o)    Miscellaneous affairs.
   (p)    Adjournment.
   On motion of any Councilperson, the order of business at any meeting may be
altered by affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members present.
(Ord. 08-16.  Passed 5-19-08.)
121.14  ADJOURNMENT; RECESS.
   Following roll call and reading of the journal of the preceding meeting or
waiver thereof, the business of regular meetings shall commence at the point
where the order of business at the preceding meeting was interrupted by the
adjournment, unless the order of business is altered as provided in Section
121.13.
(1980 Code 30.24)
121.15  COMMITTEES.
   (a)    Appointment of Committees. The following standing committees
consisting of three members each are authorized. Appointment of members to
these committees shall be made by the President Pro Tempore of the Council:
      (1)    Finance.
      (2)    Rules and Personnel.
      (3)    Service and Safety.
      (4)    Streets and Sidewalks.
      (5)    Building and Grounds.
       (6)    Public Utilities.
         (Ord. 00-66.  Passed 11-20-00.)
   (b)    The President  Pro Tempore, with the consent of Council, may appoint
such special committees as he deems necessary provided that matters referred to
or pending before a standing committee may not, without consent of its members,
be referred to or considered by a special committee.
   (c)    Committee of the Whole.  The President Pro Tempore shall preside when
Council resolves itself into the committee of the whole.
   (d)    Meetings. Committees shall meet on call of the Chairman, or on
request of two members. Two members must be present to constitute a quorum.
   (e)    The Chairman of the committee shall act as Secretary to each
committee and shall keep a record of attendance and business transacted at
meetings thereof. (1980 Code 30.25)
   (f)    The President Pro Tempore of Council shall be a member of all Council
committees but shall have no vote except in the case of a tie vote among other
committee members.
(Ord. 11-18.  Passed 7-11-11.)
121.16  COMMITTEE MEETINGS TO BE OPEN: PUBLIC NOTICE.
   (a)    All meetings of committees of Council are hereby declared to be open
to the public. Such meetings shall be called by the chairman or the Mayor at
such times as is convenient for the membership and may be called at a regular
or special meeting of Council or at such other times by notice to the
membership of the committee, the Mayor and to the Clerk of Council. The notice
shall include the agenda for the meeting. Unless otherwise stated, all meetings
shall be held at the Lexington Municipal Building.
   (b)    No meeting shall be held prior to giving twenty-four hours notice to
the news media which has requested notification except in the case of an
emergency requiring immediate official action. In the event of such an
emergency, the chairman shall notify the news media requesting notification
immediately of the date, place, time and agenda of the meeting.
   (c)    The Chairman shall arrange for the preparation and approval of
minutes of all committee meetings in accordance with established rules of
Council. All such minutes shall be filed and maintained by the Clerk of Council
and shall be open for public inspection.
(1980 Code 30.251)
   (d)    Committees may go into executive session in the same manner and for
the same reasons that Council may do so under Ohio R.C. 121.22, but no member
of Village Council or the Mayor may be excluded from any executive session of a
committee meeting unless the topic of that meeting involves misconduct of the
Council member proposed to be excluded or the misconduct or compensation of the
Mayor.  (Ord. 11-18.  Passed 7-11-11.)
   (e)    Any person who desires advance notice of any committee meeting at
which any specific type of business is to be discussed shall state in writing
to the Clerk of Council the business which is of interest and shall supply
stamped self-addressed envelopes for the purpose of such notice. The Clerk of
Council is hereby directed to keep a list of the time, date, place and agenda
of all committee meetings and make the same available to any person upon
request.
(1980 Code 30.251)
121.17  MOTIONS.
   When a motion is made, it shall require a second and shall be stated by the
Chair before debate. Unless otherwise required by law, a motion shall be deemed
passed if it receives the affirmative vote of a majority of the members present
including the Chair if entitled to vote thereon.
(1980 Code 30.26)
121.18  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.
   The latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order shall govern all proceedings
by Council except those matters covered in this chapter or otherwise expressly
controlled by the Constitution of this state, Charter of this Municipality,
applicable State statutes, or other ordinances or resolutions of this
Municipality.
(1980 Code 30.27)
121.19  SOLE CREATOR OF TITLES AND POSITIONS.
   No title or position shall be created and no appointment made to any created
title or position among the employees of this Municipality without the express
consent of Council.
(1980 Code 30.28)
121.20  COUNCIL PARLIAMENTARIAN.
   (a)   The Parliamentarian of Council is made responsible for reporting on
the status of all legislation enacted by Council.
   (b)   This report shall be made as a regular part of the agenda of each
Council meeting.
(1980 Code 32.05)
121.21 SECURITY SEARCHES.
   In the interest of protecting the safety of all persons attending any
meeting of Village Council or any committee, board or commission of this
Village, all briefcases, handbags, packages or other containers brought into
the building where the meeting is to be held are subject to search by Village
police officers.  Neither probable cause nor reasonable suspicion shall be
required for this search.
(Ord. 12-24.  Passed 9-4-12.)

   The following locations are designated as the five public places for the
posting of ordinances and resolutions adopted by Council:
   (a)   Lexington Municipal Building, 44 West Main Street.
   (b)   Lexington Branch, Mansfield-Richland County Public Library, 25 Lutz
Avenue.
   (c)   Kell Hardware, 15 West Main Street.
   (d)   Geyer's Super Valu, 280 East Main Street.
   (e)   Richland Trust Co., 276 East Main Street.
      (1980 Code 10.14)

131.01  MAYOR AS CONTRACTING OFFICER.
   (a)   The Mayor is appointed Contracting Officer and shall have all powers
and duties of the Administrative Director with respect to purchasing.
   (b)   The Mayor shall serve as such Contracting Officer only in case of the
absence or disability of the Administrative Director.
(1980 Code 32.01)

133.01  ABSENCE OR INCAPACITY OF DIRECTOR.
   In the event of the absence or incapacity of the Administrative Director,
the Mayor shall assume all duties and responsibilities of that position.  The
Mayor may delegate any of these duties to the Village Consulting Engineer or
any Village employee as the Mayor may determine is appropriate in order to
maintain an acceptable level of municipal services.
(Ord. 04-22.  Passed 5-17-04.)
133.02  ADJUSTMENTS TO APPROPRIATION LINE ITEMS.
   (a)   Council hereby assigns to the Administrative Director the authority to
adjust any line item appropriation in the permanent appropriation ordinance as
amended by transferring to it an amount of money not to exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) per line item provided money is available for this purpose
either in the unappropriated reserve for the fund or by transferring money from
another line item which has not been spent and will not be needed for other
expenditures before the end of the year.
   (b)   The authority to make the transfers described in subsection (a) hereof
shall be available only to provide the money necessary to pay bills at the end
of the year which were unforeseen or resulted from an emergency situation and
no regular Council meeting is available for Council to amend the permanent
appropriation ordinance.
   (c)   Whenever the Administrative Director uses the authority provided by
this Ordinance, he/she shall provide a written summary of all such transfers to
Council at the first regular Council meeting in January of the following year. 
(Ord. 14-36.  Passed 12-15-14.)

CHAPTER 139
Police Department
139.01   Positions established.
139.02   Physical examination requirement.  (Repealed)
139.03   Departure from Municipality while on duty; use of Municipally-owned
motor vehicles, uniforms and equipment.
139.04   Residency requirements.

139.06   Auxiliary Police Force.

CROSS REFERENCES

139.01  POSITIONS ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   The Municipal Police Department shall be composed of the Chief of
Police and such additional officers and employees as may be authorized by
Council.
   (b)   These positions shall be filled only through the adoption by a
majority vote of Council of a resolution appointing a specific individual to
such position.
(1980 Code 33.01)
139.02  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION REQUIREMENT.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
139.02 was repealed by Ordinance 01-18, passed April 2, 2001.)
139.03  DEPARTURE FROM MUNICIPALITY WHILE ON DUTY; USE OF MUNICIPALLY-OWNED
MOTOR VEHICLES,  UNIFORMS, AND EQUIPMENT.
   (a)    No member of the Police Department or Police Auxiliary shall, while
on duty, leave the corporate limits of this Municipality except for the
following reasons:
      (1)    A  specific request for assistance from another law enforcement
agency or from a fire department;
      (2)    To transport a prisoner to jail or court;
      (3)    To appear in the Richland County Common Pleas Court, Richland
County Juvenile Court, Mansfield Municipal Court, before the Richland County
Grand Jury, or other court pursuant to a proper subpoena;
      (4)    To conduct an investigation of a crime which occurred within this
Municipality, including conferences with witnesses or suspects, other law
enforcement agencies, the county prosecuting attorney or the Municipal Law
Director;
      (5)    To transport a person arrested for operating a motor vehicle under
the influence of alcohol to the State Highway Patrol Post 70, Richland County
Sheriff's Department or Mansfield Police Department for an intoxilyzer test;
      (6)    In exercising the powers of fresh pursuit as defined by general
law.
   (b)    No member of the Police Department or Police Auxiliary shall, while
not on duty, do any of the following:
      (1)    Operate a Municipally-owned police cruiser;
      (2)    Wear any uniform identifying him as being employed by or
associated with this Municipality;
      (3)    Use any police equipment owned by or purchased by this
Municipality;
      (4)    Represent himself as being a member of the Police Department or
Police Auxiliary for the purpose of compelling obedience to any order or
command;
      (5)    Purport to exercise any police powers outside of this
Municipality;
      (6)    Use the name, authority, or insignia of this Municipality for the
purpose of obtaining private employment.
   (c)    Any officer who violates the provisions of this section shall be
deemed guilty of misfeasance in office.
(1980 Code 33.07)
139.04  RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    All Municipal police officers and civilian employees shall reside
within twenty miles of the Lexington Municipal Building or anywhere within
Richland County, Ohio. A map marked Exhibit A is attached to original Ordinance
91-48 showing the boundaries of this area.
   (b)    Should any Municipal police officer or civilian employee fail to
reside within the area described in subsection (a) hereof, they shall be
subject to immediate removal from office.
(1980 Code 33.08)
139.05  POLICE PROTECTION OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   Council hereby approves the providing of police protection to any city,
village, county or township of this State or to a governmental entity  of an 
adjoining state and to provide complex investigation, critical response,
rescue, emergency or disaster situation assistance whenever necessary upon
proper authorization.
   Police protection and assistance shall be extended only upon authorization
of the Chief of Police, on the exercise of that officer's discretion, taking
into account that such police protection or other mutual aid may be extended
only so far as is consistent with the proper protection of the Municipality
which shall have priority at all times for Municipal Police personnel and
equipment.
(1980 Code 33.09)
139.06  AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE.
   (a)   Creation; Appointment; Members.
      (1)    There is created an Auxiliary Police Force consisting of special
policemen to be known as Auxiliary Policemen.
      (2)    At no time shall the membership of such Auxiliary Police Force
exceed fifteen members.
   (b)   Service. Auxiliary Police shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor or
until their resignation shall have been accepted by the Mayor.
(1980 Code 33.10 - 33.15)
   (c)   Qualifications; Age and Residency.  Members of the Auxiliary Police
force shall reside within twenty miles of the Lexington Municipal Building or
anywhere within Richland County, Ohio and shall not be less than twenty-one
years of age at the time of their appointment.
(Ord.  99-2.  Passed 1-18-99.)
   (d)   Commanding Officer.  The Chief of Police shall be the Commanding
Officer of the Auxiliary Police Force and shall have control of the assigning,
training, stationing, and working of such force.
   (e)   Powers. Auxiliary Police, when so acting and when in the prescribed
uniform, shall have all police powers of the ordinary members of the Police
Force. They shall obey the orders given to them by the Chief of Police and any
chain of command in the Police Department that he may designate.
   (f)   Rules And Regulations. The Mayor shall  prescribe the rules and
regulations for the conduct and control of the Auxiliary Police Force. He shall
prescribe the uniform, badge, or other designation to be used by such force. No
member of such force shall be assigned or sent on any assignment outside the
Municipality.
(1980 Code 33.10 - 33.15)
139.07  SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS.
   (a)   Creation. There is created the positions of Special School Crossing
Guards for the Municipality.
   (b)   Appointment. Special School Crossing Guards shall be appointed by the
Chief of Police in such number as are necessary to man those crossings
established by the Council.
   (c)   Payment. The Special School Crossing Guards shall be paid a daily rate
to be established by Council.
   (d)   Responsibility. The School Guards shall be responsible for the safety
of school children and other pedestrians coming to and going from all schools
within the Municipality, and for this purpose shall have the authority to
direct and regulate motor vehicle and pedestrian traffic in and near duly
established school zones.
   (e)   Serving. The School Crossing Guards shall serve at such times and
places and perform such duties as they are directed by the Mayor or the Police
Chief.
   (f)   Not to Have Police Powers. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to
grant to the School Crossing Guards any police powers beyond those specifically
enumerated in this section.
(1980 Code 33.20 - 33.25)

CHAPTER 152
Electronic and Communication Steering Committee
152.01   Definition.
152.02   Creation.
152.03   Meetings; duties; quorum.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR. 
7.09
Organization - vacancies - see CHTR.
  7.10
 
 
 
152.01  DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, electronic and communications equipment and
services shall include all purchases or leases of computer hardware and
software, telephone and radio systems, including upgrades and other changes to
current equipment, web pages, internet access and all other decisions that
affect the ability of Village employees to communicate or to create, store or
retrieve data. 
(Ord.  00-65.  Passed 11-20-00.)
152.02  CREATION.
   There is hereby created the Electronic and Communication Steering Committee,
hereinafter ECSC, which shall be composed of the following:
   (a)   Mayor.
   (b)   One member of Council appointed by the President Pro Tempore of
Council.
   (c)   Administrative Director.
   (d)   Finance Director/Assistant Finance Director.
   (e)   Police Chief.
   (f)   Two citizens of the Village knowledgeable in communications or
information systems appointed by the Mayor.
      (Ord.  00-65.  Passed 11-20-00.)
152.03  MEETINGS; DUTIES; QUORUM.
   The ECSC shall meet at the request of the Mayor or any two members and shall
review and consider all proposed communication and electronic equipment and
service decisions.  The Committee may, by motion, recommend to Council the
purchase, lease, or other acquisition of such equipment or services.  The
decision to recommend shall be by motion with each member of the Committee
entitled to one vote; provided, however, that the Mayor may vote only in the
case of a tie.  A majority of the Committee shall constitute a quorum and an
affirmative vote by a majority of a quorum present shall constitute a
recommendation of the Committee.  This Committee shall be considered a standing
committee for the purpose of the rule of Council requiring all legislation to
come from a standing committee.  All meetings shall be open to the public
except that executive sessions may be called as provided by law; minutes of all
meetings shall be kept in the same manner as committees of Council and the
procedure generally followed by Council committees shall be used except where
it is clearly inapplicable.
(Ord.  00-65.  Passed 11-20-00.)

CHAPTER 155
Shade Tree Commission
155.01   Definitions.

CROSS REFERENCES
